title-group.article-title: The synergistic effect of benzo[a]pyrene and lead on learning and memory of mice

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Occupational and Environmental Medicine, School of Public Health, Chongqing Medical University, Chongqing, People’s Republic of China
2Department of Occupational and Environmental Medicine, School of Public Health, Luzhou Medical College, Luzhou, People’s Republic of China
3Department of Environmental Health, West China School of Public Health, Sichuan University, Chengdu, People’s Republic of China
4Department of Health Statistics and Data Management, School of Public Health, Chongqing Medical University, Chongqing, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Tu Baijie, Department of Occupational and Environmental Medicine, School of Public Health, Chongqing Medical University, Chongqing 400016, People’s Republic of China. Email: baijietu@hotmail.com

abstract.p: In the present study, the single and combined neurotoxic effects of benzo[a]pyrene ([BaP] 0.0, 0.5, and 5.0 mg/kg body weight; intragastric administration) and lead acetate (0.0, 5.4, and 54.0 mg/L; by drinking water) were examined on KunMing mice. In the Morris water maze, results showed that BaP and lead induced synergistic effects on the escape latency and the time spent in the target quadrant but also showed an additive effect on the number of times animal crossing the original platform. Also, BaP and lead induced a synergistic effect on DNA damage in the single-cell gel electrophoresis. However, BaP plus lead showed additive effects on the levels of malondialdehyde, superoxide dismutase, and glutathione. These results suggested that the combination of BaP and lead can lead to a synergistic effect on spatial learning and memory impairments, and the mechanisms of the synergistic effects on behavioral deficits may be due to the oxidative stress injury.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Both benzo[a]pyrene (BaP) and lead are ubiquitous environmental pollutants. BaP, a prototypic polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), is formed during the incomplete burning of coal, oil, gas, wood, garbage, or other organic substances, such as tobacco and charbroiled meat (ATSDR, 1995). Lead (Pb2+) exposure is also a public health problem of global magnitude because of the widespread environmental contamination, propensity to cause a wide spectrum of toxic effects, and the number of individuals affected worldwide (Toscano and Guilarte, 2005). People are also at great risk of exposure to lead and BaP at the same time. Nowadays, BaP is one of the most widely studied PAHs. Chronic exposure to BaP can cause damage to brain, lung, skin, ovary, testes, kidney, stomach, and colon, and the carcinogenicity of BaP is also well established (Arafa et al., 2009; Saunders et al., 2001). Otherwise, chronic lead exposure can produce changes in the structure and function of the blood and hematopoietic system, nervous system, digestive system, blood vessels, and kidneys (Alghazal et al., 2008; Bagchi and Preuss, 2005; Kaminski and Pawlica, 1983; Lin et al., 2006; Zhong et al., 2010).

In spite of the extensive documentation of neurotoxicity of BaP and lead individually, the neurotoxicity of the combination of BaP and lead is relatively obscure except on female fertility in mice (Kristensen et al., 1995). The results suggest that lead and BaP have synergistic effects on the impairment of fertility. The mixture of lead, cadmium, and arsenic exposure during brain development also has greater than additive response on astrocyte toxicity with adverse impacts on blood–brain barrier function that culminate into neurological deficits in developing rats (Rai et al., 2010). Therefore, much more attention should be paid to the synergistic effects of ubiquitous environmental pollutants.

The purpose of this study was to investigate BaP and lead for their interactive effects on neurotoxicity in KunMing (KM) mice. Previous studies have demonstrated that exposure to BaP (Grova et al., 2007; Xia et al., 2011; Zhang et al., 2008) and lead (Banni et al., 2010; Gao et al., 2005; Song et al., 2006) led to impairments of learning and spatial memory in the Morris water maze (MWM) tests. Therefore, MWM was conducted to determine whether chronic BaP or lead exposure can alter learning and memory performance of mice, and whether BaP plus lead have an interactive effect on this behavioral test. Furthermore, to explore the potential mechanisms, the DNA damage of neuron in the hippocampus was estimated by single-cell gel electrophoresis ([SCGE] comet assay), and the potential effects on oxidative stress was also investigated.

sec.title: Animals and treatment
sec.p: A total of 80 healthy male KM mice, aged 21 days, obtained from Chongqing Medical University Lab Animal Center, were used in this study. KM mice are the most widely used outbred colony in China. The animals were maintained on a 12-h light/12-h dark cycle (light on at 8:00 a.m.) in a temperature-controlled room (25 ± 1°C) and relative humidity within 50 ± 10% and water and food were available ad libitum. Before treatment, animals were given a 7-day acclimation period to the laboratory condition. All animal procedures were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of Chongqing Medical University and in accordance with the policy of the Ethical Committee, State Key Laboratory of Reproductive Biology, Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences.

All the 80 mice were randomly divided into 10 groups, as follow: (a) control group; (b) vehicle group; (c) low-dose lead acetate group (5.4 mg/L); (d) high-dose lead acetate (54 mg/L); (e) low-dose BaP (0.5 mg/kg); (f) high-dose BaP (5 mg/kg); (g) low-dose lead acetate + low-dose BaP; (h) low-dose lead acetate + high-dose BaP; (i) high-dose lead acetate + low-dose BaP; (j) high-dose lead acetate + high-dose BaP (shown in Table 1). BaP and lead acetate were purchased from Sigma Chemical Co. (St. Louis, Missouri, USA). BaP, which dissolved in sesame oil, was administered every day intragastrically, while lead acetate which dissolved in drinking water was given every day. The dose levels of BaP used in this study correspond to levels of heavy consumers of smoked or grilled meat and fish, or individuals who live in the heavy PAHs polluted areas, etc. (ATSDR, 1995). Also, the dose levels of lead acetate was relevant to the toxic range of lead.

tr.td: Sesame oil is given in parallel by intraperitoneal injection
5.4 mg/L lead acetate + 0.5 mg/kg bw BaP
5.4 mg/L lead acetate + 5.0 mg/kg bw BaP
54.0 mg/L lead acetate + 0.5 mg/kg bw BaP
54.0 mg/L lead acetate + 5.0 mg/kg bw BaP

sec.p: After 30 days exposure, the effects of BaP and lead acetate on behavior were evaluated by MWM. After behavioral test, the animals were killed and the hippocampus was isolated. Samples were stored at −80°C until further use.

sec.title: Morris water maze
sec.p: The water maze consisted of a pool with a diameter of 100 cm, 40 cm high filled with tap water to a depth of 25 cm, adjusted to 22 ± 1°C, and made opaque by the addition of powdered white nontoxic tempera paint. The pool was placed in a 2.5 × 3 × 2.5 m3 rectangular room containing invariant spatial stimuli. A circular escape platform of 9 cm in diameter was placed 1 cm below the surface of the water in the middle of one of the four quadrants of the pool, and this position remained constant throughout testing. A video camera suspended from the ceiling above the center of the pool was used to monitor the animals’ behavior. All animals were allowed to circumnavigate the pool in search of the escape platform for a maximum of 60 s. Place training consisted of four trials each day for 4 consecutive days. In each trial, a mouse was lowered by hand into the pool and placed in the water facing the inside wall of the pool at one of the four start positions that were spaced equally around the rim of the pool. The start points used for each trial varied in a pseudo-random sequence. Latency of reaching the escape platform was recorded. If a mouse did not reach the platform within 60 s, it was guided to the platform by the experimenter, left on the platform for 10 s, and assigned a latency score of 60 s for that trial. Animals were returned to a holding cage for 60 s between trials. On the final trial of day 5, the mice were given a 60-s retention test of the location with the platform absent. The numbers of crossing of the exact location of the platform and the time spent in the target quadrant were recorded.

sec.title: Single-cell gel electrophoresis
sec.p: The SCGE test was basically performed according to the method described by Singh et al. (1988). Briefly, a 10-μL hippocampus suspension sample mixed with 110 μL of 0.5% low melting point agarose was transferred to a microscope slide (previously dipped in 1.0% normal melting point agarose). After allowing the low melting point agarose to solidify by putting the slide on a cooled metal plate for 2 min, the cover glass was carefully removed. On the slide, 75 μL of 0.5% low melting point agarose was placed as the top layer and covered with a cover glass again. When the top layer of agarose solidified, the cover glass was carefully removed and the slides submersed into a lysis solution (2.5 M NaCl, 100 mM disodium salt of ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 10; 1% Triton X-100 and 10% dimethyl sulfoxide were added freshly before use) at 4°C for 2 h to remove cellular proteins. Slides were then placed in a horizontal gel electrophoresis tank filled with fresh electrophoresis buffer (1 mM EDTA, 300 mM NaOH, pH 13) and left in the solution for 40 min at 4°C to allow the DNA to unwind and the alkali labile damage to occur. Electrophoresis was then performed at 25 V, 300 mA for 30 min. Later, the slides were removed from the electrophoresis tank, neutralized with 3 × 5 min washes with Tris-HCl (0.4 M, pH 7.5), and stained with 50 μL of ethidium bromide (0.05 mM). DNA migration, which looks like a comet, was viewed by a fluorescence microscope (Axioskop 2 plus, Zeiss). Percentage of DNA in tail, which was analyzed by CASP comet assay software, was chosen as an index for DNA damage. A total of 50 cells per slide and two slides per sample were scored in this test. After that the means and the SD of each treatment were calculated.

sec.title: Oxidative stress—MDA, GSH, and SOD
sec.p: The hippocampus were cut into smaller fragments, weighed, and homogenized in ice-cold 20 mM Tris-HCl buffer (pH 7.4) and centrifuged for 15 min at a temperature of 4°C at 15,000 r/min. The supernatants were decanted and used to estimate lipid peroxidation by malondialdehyde (MDA), glutathione (GSH), and superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity kit and protein assay kit (Nanjing Jiancheng Bioengineering Institute, China). MDA was measured at a wavelength of 532 nm by reacting with thiobarbituric acid to form a stable chromophoric production. GSH was assayed at a wavelength of 412 nm by a method that utilized 5,5-dithiobis (2-nitrobenzoic acid) for color development. Activity of SOD was measured by the method described by Misra and Fridovich (1972) at a wavelength of 550 nm. Total protein concentration in the supernatants was quantified by the technique of Lowry et al. (1951). Then, MDA, GSH, and SOD activity was calculated according to the instructions on the kits. All analyses were performed as recommended by manufacturers of the reagent kits.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was carried out in SPSS 17.0 software (SPSS Inc., Chicago, Illinois, USA). The data of control group and vehicle group were grouped together as one group on the condition that there is no significant difference between the two groups. The one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to evaluate single toxic effect of BaP or lead in mice. The factorial ANOVA test was used to evaluate the main effect and interactive effect of BaP and lead in mice. p < 0.05 was considered to indicate statistical significance.

sec.title: MWM test
sec.p: In the MWM test, compared with the controls, both BaP- and lead-exposed animals showed significant increase in the escape latency (F = 58.562, p < 0.001; F = 51.148, p < 0.001); however, the numbers crossing the exact location of the platform (F = 6.030, p = 0.006; F = 4.122, p = 0.027) and the time spent in the target quadrant (F = 13.194, p < 0.001; F = 20.541, p < 0.001) were significantly decreased. Factorial ANOVA results indicated that lead and BaP induced synergistic toxic effects on the escape latency (F = 5.800, p < 0.001) and the time spent in target quadrant (F = 2.806, p = 0.032), while they induced additive toxic effect on the numbers crossing the exact location of the platform (F = 0.045, p = 0.996; Figure 1).

caption.p: The effects of BaP plus lead on learning and memory performance in MWM. Values were mean ± SD. (a) The effects of BaP plus lead on the level of escape latency in MWM. The BaP-/lead-exposed animals showed a significant increase in the escape latency (F = 58.562, p < 0.001/F = 51.148, p < 0.001). Factorial ANOVA results indicate that lead and BaP induced a synergistic toxic effect on the escape latency (F 0.05,4 = 5.800, p < 0.001). (b) The effects of BaP plus lead on the level of frequency of crossing platform in MWM. The BaP-/lead-exposed animals showed a significant increase in the frequency of crossing the platform (F = 6.030, p = 0.006/F = 4.122, p = 0.027). Factorial ANOVA results indicate that lead and BaP induced an additive effect on the frequency of crossing platform (F 0.05,4 = 0.045, p = 0.996). (c) The effects of BaP plus lead on the level of time spent in target quadrant in MWM. The BaP-/lead-exposed animals showed a significant increase in the time spent in the target quadrant (F = 13.194, p < 0.001/F = 20.541, p < 0.001). Factorial ANOVA results indicate that lead and BaP induced a synergistic toxic effect on the time spent in target quadrant (F 0.05,4 = 2.806, p = 0.032). BaP: benzo[a]pyrene; MWM: Morris water maze; ANOVA: analysis of variance.

sec.title: Analysis of apoptosis
sec.p: SCGE was conducted to evaluate DNA damage of hippocampal neuron in mice. Both BaP- and lead-exposed animals showed a significant increase in the percentage of DNA in tail (F = 9.823, p = 0.001; F = 5.226, p = 0.012). Factorial ANOVA results showed that lead and BaP induced a synergistic effect on DNA damage (F = 3.530, p = 0.011; Figures 2 and 3).

caption.p: The effects of BaP plus lead on the percentage of DNA in tail. Values were mean ± SD. The BaP-/lead-exposed animals showed a significant increase in percentage DNA in tail (F = 9.823, p = 0.001/F = 5.226, p = 0.012). Factorial ANOVA results show that lead and BaP have a synergistic effect on DNA damage (F 0.05,4 = 3.530, p = 0.011). BaP: benzo[a]pyrene; ANOVA: analysis of variance.

(a) Vehicle group, (b) low-dose lead acetate group, (c) high-dose lead acetate group, (d) low-dose BaP group, (e) high-dose BaP group, (f) low-dose lead acetate + low-dose BaP group, (g) low-dose lead acetate + high-dose BaP group, (h) high-dose lead acetate + low-dose BaP group, and (i) high-dose lead acetate + high-dose BaP group. BaP: benzo[a]pyrene.

sec.title: Oxidative stress
sec.p: In order to explore the potential mechanisms for synergistic effect of BaP and lead, the oxidative stress indicators such as MDA, GSH, and SOD were also tested. Results showed that the content of GSH in the vehicle group (97.69 ± 4.54) was significantly lower than that of the control group (148.66 ± 4.38). Thus, the content of GSH in the vehicle group was calculated for the next statistical analysis. The BaP-exposed animals showed a significant increase in MDA (F = 7.134, p = 0.003); however, the content of SOD (F = 137.844, p < 0.001) and GSH (F = 28.802, p < 0.001) were significantly decreased. The lead-exposed animals showed significant decreases in the levels of SOD (F = 34.843, p < 0.001) and GSH (F = 14.597, p < 0.001), while the levels of MDA showed an increase but this difference did not reach statistical significance when compared with the vehicle controls (F = 2.614, p = 0.090). The factorial ANOVA test demonstrated that lead and BaP induced additive toxic effects, rather than synergistic toxic effect, on the levels of MDA (F = 2.016, p = 0.101), SOD (F = 0.865, p = 0.489), and GSH (F = 2.371, p = 0.062; Figure 4).

caption.p: The effects of BaP plus lead on oxidative stress. Values were mean ± SD. (a) The effects of BaP plus lead on the level of MDA. The BaP-/lead-exposed animals showed an increasing trend in MDA (F = 7.134, p = 0.003/F = 2.614, p = 0.090), but the lead-exposed animals did not show significant difference. Factorial ANOVA test demonstrates that lead and BaP induced an additive toxic effect on the level of MDA (F 0.05,4 = 2.016, p = 0.101). (b) The effects of BaP plus lead on the level of SOD. The BaP-/lead-exposed animals showed a significant decrease in SOD (F = 137.844, p < 0.001/F = 34.843, p < 0.001). Factorial ANOVA test demonstrates that lead and BaP induced an additive toxic effect on the level of SOD (F 0.05,4 = 0.865, p = 0.489). (c) The effects of BaP plus lead on the level of GSH. The BaP-/lead-exposed animals showed a significant decrease in GSH (F = 28.802, p < 0.001/F = 14.597, p < 0.001). Factorial ANOVA test demonstrates that lead and BaP induced an additive toxic effect on the level of GSH (F 0.05,4 = 2.371, p = 0.062). BaP: benzo[a]pyrene; ANOVA: analysis of variance; MDA: malondialdehyde; GSH: glutathione; SOD: superoxide dismutase.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: To our knowledge, the combined neurotoxic effects of BaP and lead on central nervous system have not been reported earlier. These experiments showed that BaP plus lead could lead to synergistic effects on learning and memory impairments and neuronal DNA damage; however, BaP plus lead induced additive toxic effects on oxidative stress in the hippocampus.

The hippocampus is a critical structure for spatial learning and memory. Besides, DNA damage was considered to be consistent with the impairment of learning and memory abilities (Feng et al., 2010). In the present study, SCGE was conducted to evaluate DNA damage of hippocampus cell in mice. The results suggested that BaP plus lead has a synergistic effect on the percentage of DNA in tail.

Many agents which induce apoptosis are either oxidants or stimulators of cellular oxidative metabolism. Conversely, many inhibitors of apoptosis have antioxidant activities or enhance cellular antioxidant defenses (Buttke and Sandstrom, 1994). Oxidative stress is defined as the imbalance between biochemical processes leading to the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and those responsible for the removal of ROS, the so-called antioxidant cascade (Sayre et al., 2008). Previous studies have demonstrated that both BaP and lead can lead to oxidative stress (Costa et al., 2010; Gao et al., 2011; Kumar et al., 2010; Wang et al., 2009). The ROS produced in the oxidative stress are short-lived and difficult to assess in vitro and in vivo. Measurement of considerably more stable oxidation products left by ROS in biological fluids and tissues is a generally accepted and widely applied method to quantitate the extent of oxidative stress in various conditions (Dreissigacker et al., 2010). The ROS can result in lipid peroxidation of (poly)unsaturated fatty acids and oxidation of some specific proteins (Mates et al., 2000). MDA, one of aldehydes, the prominent product of lipid peroxidation of (poly)unsaturated fatty acids, is a widely recognized biomarker of oxidative stress of lipid peroxidation and has been studied most frequently. Therefore, the amount of MDA, rather than ROS, in biological fluids and tissues is used to evaluate the extent of oxidative stress (Dreissigacker et al., 2010) and can indirectly reflect the degree of cell damage in various conditions. SOD plays an important role in the balance of body’s oxidation and antioxidant (Isler et al., 2002). While the activity of SOD is reduced, OH and O2− which accumulated during body metabolism can attack unsaturated fatty acids in biofilm and can lead to lipid peroxidation. GSH is a low-molecular-weight, free radical scavenger that can clear O2−,H2O2, and LOOH (El-Sokkary et al., 2002). GSH is a three-peptide consisting of one molecular methionine, one molecular glycine, and one molecular cysteine. It is a nonprotein thiol and is a substrate of both glutathione peroxidase (GSH-PX) and glutathione-S-transferase (GST) enzyme. It is necessary for both GSH-PX and GST enzyme as a substrate for decomposition of hydrogen peroxide. GSH also can stabilize the enzymes containing thiol and prevents hemoglobin and other cofactors from oxidative damage. The lack or depletion of GSH will lead to chemical substances or environmental factors producing toxic effects or increasing its toxicity. This may be related to the increased oxidative damage, and thus the amount of GSH is an important indicator for measuring the antioxidant capacity (Savolainen et al., 1998). In oxidative stress test, BaP plus lead showed additive effects on the levels of MDA, SOD, and GSH.

In conclusion, this study emphasizes that BaP plus lead can lead to synergistic effect on learning and memory impairments. In other words, the combination of BaP and lead exposure has greater than additive response on learning and memory ability in developing rats. The interactive effect of DNA damage and oxidative stress may play an important role in this event. In addition, in the analysis of interactive effect, we also found that the effects of combination on behavioral performance are unequivalent with the effects on oxidative stress. This study underscores the importance of synergistic action of ubiquitous environmental pollutants.

fn.label: Conflict of interest
fn.p: The authors declared no conflicts of interest.

fn.p: This study was supported by the National Science Foundation of China (grant number: 81041077).
